description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Ministry of National Security informs public that it is prepared to take necessary action against persons if necessary, for the maintenance of public order. With regards to reckless statements being made on social media, the relevant authority will be reviewing our current laws to determine if persons can be prosecuted for making uniformed, irresponsible statements.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: PM of Trinidad and Tobago advices all schools, universities, and other places of learning to close down for at least one week from 14. March onwards, after reporting the first COVID-19 case two days previously.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
school_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: With Trinidad and Tobago's announcement to extent the lockdown, schools are also expected to remain closed until May 15th at least. This was announced in a statement by the PM on April 26th.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: On 29 January, Trinidad and Tobago urges those thinking about going to China for non-essential travel not to go.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago imposes a 14 day travel restriction for persons departing China. All people who have been to China over the past two weeks have to spend a 14 day incubation period in a non-risk country before entering T&T again.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on 9 February that travel restrictions remain in place and no end date can be provided at this point. The Minister of Health advises TT nationals in China to remain there whether they are symptomatic or not, the reason provided being that it would be riskier for them to fly back on full planes and pass through crowded airports than to stay put. It is stated that those who want to return will not be refused entry into the country, but will be put under self-isolation.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago enforces fever scanners at the Piarco International airport, targeting flights from North America, the UK and Panama; starting January 22. People over 37.2 are questioned on their travel history, and if necessary quarantined and the country's infectious disease protocol will be enforced.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago expands travel restrictions to five additional countries (Italy, South Korea, Singapore, Japan, Iran), starting February 27. These measures were previously only applied to China. All travellers who have been to one of these regions are required to spend a 14 day incubation period in a non-risk region, before being allowed to enter the country again.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago Minister of Health announces that as of 2 March, all non-essential travel of ministry personnel has stopped.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 4 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges public to use common sense with regard to international travel. Minister of Health states that public can travel internationally if absolutely necessary, but is urged to reconsider if the travel can be delayed, such as in the case of a birthday celebration or wedding.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago extend the travel restrictions to Spain, France and Germany. Individuals who have been to one of these regions have to remain in a non-risk region for a 14 day incubation period. After it has been assured that they have developed no symptoms, they are allowed to enter the country again; starting March 11.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 13 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces the suspension of all cruise ships visits to the country until the end of cruise ship season (24 April).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: On 13 March, Trinidad and Tobago tells public to only engage in essential and emergency travel.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago restricts all entry for the next 14 days except for nationals, starting midnight March 17 and is supposed to last for 14 days. Exemptions can be granted in certain circumstances e.g. for CARPHA members and cargo ships.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago closes international borders to all travelers, including Trinidad and Tobago nationals, and suspend all commercial flights into the country as of midnight on 22 March.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago enforces preparation in health facilities for an eventual (major) COVID-19 by adding hospital beds, and enabling whole hospitals to be operationalised for isolation capacity; announced February 27.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on 4 March that its hospitals are prepared to address COVID-19 with sufficient basic personal protective equipment stock, which will be made available as needed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on 4 March that its hospitals are prepared to address COVID-19 with sufficient basic personal protective equipment stock, which will be made available as needed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 6 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces strengthening of its disaster response through handover of relief items to national response and recovery agencies, to strengthen the capacity of first responders throughout all 14 municipalities.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago expands COVID-19 testing possibilities with the aim to test anyone who meets testing criteria. Two additional PCR machines are placed at the two facilities: one at EWMSC and the other at the Trinidad Public Health Laboratory by the end of the week to assist in expanding testing, starting March 23rd.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Trinidad and Tobago, the charitable organisation Foundation for the Enhancement and Enrichment of Life (FEEL) has received the first tranche of 10,000 cloth masks, which are ordered to be distributed to the public free of charge. Furthermore, Minister Deyalsingh noted that pharmacies should not be selling N95 masks to the general public as they should be reserved for front line medical workers.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago designates treatment centre for up to 72 individuals at the Trinidad and Tobago Football Association’s (TTFA) Home of Football building. It offers it free of costs and the facility is expected to start functioning on April 30th.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces that, as of 4 March, 25 samples have been submitted to the Caribbean Public Health Agency for testing, of which 0 have tested positive.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on 4 March that 'exit screenings' are being arranged at international airports in Canada, the UK and USA
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: As of 23 March 2020, COVID-19 testing in Trinidad and Tobago has been expanded. The Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) will expand its testing to test anyone who meets any of the criteria for COVID-19 exposure.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago starts training program for the PCR machines, including 50 individuals, announced April 16th 2020.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: In Trinidad and Tobago, from Monday 27th April, there will be an increase in COVID-19 testing, with up to 50 Surveillance Tests per day. Chief Medical Officer (CMO) Dr Roshan Parasram confirmed that the increased testing capacity is necessary to determine whether there is COVID-19 community spread in Trinidad and Tobago. The Ministry of Health is expected to complete up to 700 tests.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges citizens to stay at home.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on April 26th an extension of the stay-at-home order until March 15th. According to president Keith Rowley, the extension has become necessary to allow health officials to expand testing. Dr Rowley has urged members of the public to stay at home, continue with good hygiene, and practice physical distancing. On March 10th, a new statement will be made public on whether the country is able to relax its policy.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces that starting on June 22nd 2020, the public will be allowed to access beaches and rivers again. In order to prevent a spreading of the virus, their access had been banned until now.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces the establishment of a standing committee to deal with public health concerns and emerging infectious diseases, February 27.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago has announced to creation of Cabinet Sub Committees which will focus on education, finance and the social impact of COVID-19, March 16th.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago announced working on a report on COVID-19 impact on the nations economy. A first draft is expected at the end of April. Members include a team of the Ministry of Finance and UWI Professor Karl Theodore.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of 23 March, in Trinidad and Tobago, citizens are being urged to not send their samples to private labs who claim to be doing rapid COVID-19 tests. These private labs are not equipped with PCR machines and therefore the results will be inaccurate.
type_text: Recommendation to citizens on coronavirus-related crime
enforcer: National Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago, as of April 16th, the government has received more than 38,000 Salary Relief Grant applications and they are evaluated by the Ministry of Finance.
type_text: An economic policy that provides assistance for all citizens that report a loss in income due to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago holds a media briefing in which medical epidemiologist at the Ministry of Health, Dr Avery Hinds, explains to the public the concepts behind contact tracing, how that relates to quarantine and how those procedures limit spread, so that the public understands the basis behind the request to stay at home.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 25 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Ministry of Health advises the population of a fake news post. It states that members of the public are not authorised to use the official letterhead of the Ministry of Health, in any form, and should refrain from doing so. The public is urged to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces that  persons returning to T&T are asked to put themselves under self-quarantine for 14 days. There is a fine of $6000 for persons in breach of quarantine orders.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces that visiting hours at all public hospitals are now restricted to one session per day (in the afternoon 4pm - 6pm). Patients will only be allowed one visitor however, on-duty staff will be able to use their discretion, on a case by case basis.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government

description: On 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges citizens to stay at home.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 13 March, Trinidad and Tobago advises managers and business owners to implement realistic sick leave policies, be flexible with workplace arrangements, allow people to work from home where feasible and act on Public Health recommendations.
enforcer: National Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago encourages closure of private businesses and other non-essential businesses or to work from home, starting on March 15th.
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago encourages closure of private businesses and other non-essential businesses or to work from home, starting on March 15th.
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 15 March, Trinidad and Tobago encourages employers to implement remote work policies for employees with children. If that is not possible, employers are encouraged to explore options of shift work, staggered hours of work and/or rostering. Where alternative work arrangements cannot be made, the employee is to be allowed to stay at home with his/her children without being penalized by either disciplinary action or by non-payment of salary.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 15 March, Trinidad and Tobago encourages employers to implement remote work policies for employees with children. If that is not possible, employers are encouraged to explore options of shift work, staggered hours of work and/or rostering. Where alternative work arrangements cannot be made, the employee is to be allowed to stay at home with his/her children without being penalized by either disciplinary action or by non-payment of salary.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on April 26th that restrictions placed on hardware stores would be relaxed. According to it, the stores are now allowed to open for half-day from Monday to Saturday.
enforcer: National Government

description:
Trinidad and Tobago outlines a six-step plan to reopen the economy and borders again. The next phase only starts if the previous one was implemented successfully. Below the whole 6 phases are outlined. However, due to the fact that there is still uncertainty regarding the fact whether the next phases are going to be implemented, this policy entry focuses on Phase 1.

Phase 1 (May 11-May 23) allows a slow opening of restaurants, food establishments, and vendors. All other health regulations (distance, mask and closure of non-essential businesses remains in place)

Phase 2 (May 24-June 6) entails a reopening of the country's whole manufacturing sector, public sector construction, and 50% capacity of public transportation will be allowed

Phase 3 (June 7-June 20) whole public service returns to work with flexible times (if possible), private sector construction may resume, capacity of public transportation may be increased to 75%

Phase 4: The reopening of malls and beaches

Phase 5: The reopening of cinemas.

Phase 6: The reopening of the country’s borders.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago declares an early beginning of the second phase of the country's reopening of the economy after its nationwide COVID-19 lockdown. It was initially planned for May 24th but will now already start on May 21st after a successful implementation of phase 1 and favourable testing results. Phase 2 entails a reopening of auto repair/parts & tyre shops and laundry & dry cleaning services. Furthermore, public transportation will resume to operate at a 50% capability from phase 1. Domestic workers and personal services like spas and barbershops do not experience a reopening yet but the government promises soon changes and the Ministry of Social Development will now give priority to those employed in this sector. In the meantime, the police will control that all of the restrictions are followed. Furthermore, the PM encourages businesses in his speech on May 16th to implement a No Mask/No Service policy.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago declares an early beginning of the second phase of the country's reopening of the economy after its nationwide COVID-19 lockdown. Phase 2 entails a reopening of auto repair/parts & tyre shops and laundry & dry cleaning services. Furthermore, public transportation will resume to operate at a 50% capability from phase 1. Domestic workers and personal services like spas and barbershops do not experience a reopening yet but the government promises soon changes and the Ministry of Social Development will now give priority to those employed in this sector. In the meantime, the police will control that all of the restrictions are followed. Furthermore, the PM encourages businesses in his speech on May 16th to implement a No Mask/No Service policy.

description:
Starting June 1st 2020, Trinidad and Tobago announces further relaxations of its post-COVID-19 restrictions. Its plans entail: 
- All Retail Businesses will be allowed to reopen but must close at 6 pm.
– The entire public service will be allowed to resume work from Monday. All Managers will be asked to report for duty on June 01, 2020, while other members of staff will be allowed to report for duty on a rotation (every other day).
– Hotels that have outdoor dining facilities will be allowed to serve their guests
– Maxis and taxis will be required to continue operating at 50 per cent capacity.
– Professional service providers can resume work.
– Air transport to Tobago will resume to meet the demand for flights.
– All the activities of the National Lotteries Control Board will resume.
– Gatherings will remain at 5. Funerals will be allowed to have gatherings of 10.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces further steps in the relaxation process of COVID-19 restrictions. Starting June 8th, hairdressers, barbers, spas and domestic workers will be allowed to resume operations. Also, public transportation will be allowed to operate at 75 per cent capacity (so far it was 50% capacity).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces further steps in the relaxation process of COVID-19 restrictions. Starting June 8th, hairdressers, barbers, spas and domestic workers will be allowed to resume operations. Also, public transportation will be allowed to operate at 75 per cent capacity (so far it was 50% capacity).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Starting June 22nd, Trinidad and Tobago plans a more throughout reopening of the economy. Starting that day, all public transport will be allowed to operate at 100 per cent capacity. Also, businesses such as bars, gyms, casinos, cinemas and in-house dining will be allowed to resume operations. Sporting activities will be allowed to resume without spectators.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Starting June 22nd, Trinidad and Tobago plans a more throughout reopening of the economy. Starting that day, all public transport will be allowed to operate at 100 per cent capacity. Also, businesses such as bars, gyms, casinos, cinemas and in-house dining will be allowed to resume operations. Sporting activities will be allowed to resume without spectators.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 15 March, Trinidad and Tobago informs the public that the Emperor Valley Zoo will be closed for one week.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago decides to break parliament meetings for two weeks after March 20th.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government

description: As of 23 March, Trinidad and Tobago will suspend all permanent residence and citizenship interviews until further notice.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government

description: As of 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago advises that all public transportation vehicles should operate with windows open and, where possible, limit their occupancy.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: Starting June 22nd 2020, Trinidad and Tobago plans to end the public service rotation system. This system was initially designed to limit the spread of COVID-19 but is now no longer considered necessary. Starting on Monday, all employees will be asked to return to work on a full-time basis.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Regulated government working hours (e.g. work from home policies for government workers)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 4 March, Trinidad and Tobago asks all religious leaders to revisit and adjust how their services or prayers are conducted, keeping in mind the safety of their congregation.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health

description: On 13 March, Trinidad and Tobago tells public to limit exposure to public crowds and public places and to not expose themselves unnecessarily to mass gatherings.
enforcer: National Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago discourages gatherings above 25 persons. All bars to remain closed and no in-house dining for the next 14 days and religious bodies asked to limit gatherings, starting March 16th. In case this discouragement is not sufficient, it threatens to draft legislations.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago reduces the maximum allowed size in which people are allowed to gather from 25 to 10 people, from March 18th onwards.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government

description: On 13 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces postponement of Borough Day celebrations.
enforcer: Municipal Government

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on March 30th new guidelines for the number of people that are allowed to assemble.Gatherings will remain at 5. Funerals will be allowed to have gatherings of 10, starting June 1st.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Trinidad and Tobago announces that houses of worship will be allowed to resume activities from Friday 12 June, 2020 (in a speech by the PM Keith Rowley on June 6th 2020).

The Chief Medical Officer will provide guidelines for the resumption of religious services which will include the need for sanitization and social distancing. Worshippers will be required to wear masks to attend services which should not be longer than one hour.
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges public to practice social distancing by: avoiding in-person meetings, keeping unavoidable in-person meetings short in large meeting rooms with 3 feet distance between people and no handshaking, eliminating unnecessary travel and cancelling non-essential gatherings, workshops, etc. and by limiting recreational activities where close contact is likely.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)
